head.title: Global Warming: A Will to Act?

hedline.hl1: Global Warming: A Will to Act?

abstract.p: Berl Hartman letter says John Tierney's claim (April 23 Op-Ed) that US is leading international efforts to reduce yearly emissions of greenhouse gases is ludicrous

block.p: Re ''Cheer Up, Earth Day Is Over,'' by John Tierney (column, April 23):
The claim that the United States is ''leading new international efforts to reduce yearly emissions of greenhouse gases by a greater amount than the Kyoto Protocol'' is ludicrous.
Re ''Cheer Up, Earth Day Is Over,'' by John Tierney (column, April 23):
The claim that the United States is ''leading new international efforts to reduce yearly emissions of greenhouse gases by a greater amount than the Kyoto Protocol'' is ludicrous.
United States greenhouse gas emissions rose by 16 percent from 1990 to 2004. Meanwhile, the European Union countries that signed Kyoto cut greenhouse gas emissions to 5 percent below 1990 levels.

Yes, the air today is cleaner than it was 20 years ago, but the underlying reason is federal regulations. The 1970 Clean Air Act and its successive amendments forced states to clean up their act and spurred the new technology that made it possible.
Today, global warming is imminent, yet our leaders refuse to enact limits on greenhouse gas emissions. When the government sends the right signals, technology and solutions will follow.
The writer is co-founder of the New England Chapter of Environmental Entrepreneurs.
